stem: The pediatric nurse is providing nutrition teaching to several families with infants. Based on the documentation in the Infant Feeding & Nutrition Guide, match each food/intervention with the correct age for introduction.

tabs.title: Nurses' Notes
tabs.content:
Patient A: 4-month-old female. Parents want to know if they can start cereal 'to help her sleep'.
Patient B: 6-month-old male. Sits well with support. Reaching for his parents' food.
Patient C: 12-month-old female. Parents want to transition off formula.

tabs.title: Infant Feeding & Nutrition Guide
tabs.content:
Age GroupPrimary SourceNew Additions
0–6 MonthsBreast Milk / FormulaVitamin D supplement only
6–12 MonthsBreast Milk / FormulaIron-fortified cereal; Purees
12+ MonthsWhole MilkFamily foods (Cut appropriately)
Avoid < 1 yrNoneHoney; Cow's milk; Fruit juice

tabs.title: Clinical Status
tabs.content: Patient A: Doubled birth weight already. Patient B: Extrusion reflex (tongue thrusting) has disappeared.

rows.text: Feeding iron-fortified rice cereal or oatmeal (First solid food)
Transitioning from formula to whole (cow's) milk
Offering fruit juice (Limited to 4-6 oz max)

rationale.correct: Solids like iron-fortified cereal (r1) should be introduced between 4–6 months (c1) when the extrusion reflex disappears. Whole cow's milk (r2) is introduced at 12 months (c2). Honey (r3) and fruit juice (r4) should be avoided until after 1 year (c3) due to the risk of botulism and potential dental/metabolic health concerns, respectively.
clinicalPearls: Wait for the tongue thrust (extrusion) reflex to disappear before introducing solids.
Introduce one new food at a time, spaced 3-5 days apart, to monitor for allergic reactions.
Avoid giving honey to infants under 1 year of age due to the risk of botulism.

questionTrap.trap: Starting 'cereal in a bottle' at 2 months to help the infant sleep.
questionTrap.howToOvercome: Incorrect! Adding cereal to a bottle poses a significant choking hazard and does not effectively improve sleep.
